utterances: (Soundbite of movie, ""10 Things I Hate About You"")
State Sec.

CARNAHAN: Instead of bailing out big banks that created messes, to do something that actually is going to get money back into these communities, what really needs to happen out there, I think, is to have, you know, let's put this partisanship aside.
Understand that getting our economy going again is something that's good for all of us and that in Missouri the way you do that is by focusing on small businesses.
That's where jobs are created.
And so to do things to encourage them to be able to put more people on the payrolls.
Part of that's about, you know, these payroll tax cuts and other kinds of things and encourage that.

But it's also about, I think, getting this Wall Street reform done because there is a connection between the uncertainty that that's created and the chilling effect that that's had on banks, community lenders and small businesses' ability to get the financing they need to create jobs and grow their businesses.
Are you saying cut taxes for small business?
State Sec.
CARNAHAN: Absolutely.
Yeah.

I mean, we need to do that and focus on the things that really are going to create jobs and not continue to spend money on these big whether it's big banks or big oil companies, that we know is not getting back into Main Street.
But everyone says they're against bailouts.
On the other hand...
State Sec.
CARNAHAN: Well, not everyone acts on that and that's the difference.
Well, a Democratic administration said that if they didn't continue doing what the Bush administration had done, we could've been in an economic freefall, not just coming through a bad recession.
State Sec.
CARNAHAN: I know that there are lots of folks who have reasons why they thought particularly the bailout of the big banks was necessary.
I got to tell you, you got to hold people accountable for the problems they create.
If you don't, you create the wrong incentives.
Well, there will be a question facing the new Congress early next year, which is the exploration of the Bush tax cuts.
That would mean bringing back what Republicans call the death tax, the inheritance tax, and also increasing marginal tax rates for the highest earners in the country.
Should we forget about that?
Do we need the revenue too much to maintain either of those cuts?
State Sec.

CARNAHAN: Look, I think we've been playing games with this issue for way too long and to have a situation where the inheritance tax has gone to zero for one year and then is about to go back in at a higher rate doesn't make very much sense.
And common sense says that we should have something that's steady and predictable that people can plan on.
And I think it makes sense to put that in at the level that we used to have it and not have it revert back to higher levels.
I also think whatever we do, can't focus on the middle class.
We've got to make sure we're not imposing new taxes on them, and that's something that I'd continue to stand against.
But people who make more than $100,000 a year, a household that makes more than $200,000 a year, tax rates should go back up?
State Sec.
CARNAHAN: We need to consider everything, and I know that's going to be a big debate in the months to come.
Would a visit by President Obama help you or would it be a negative right now in the state?
State Sec.
CARNAHAN: The president is always welcome in Missouri.
And I'm sure he'll be back here before the election.
Well, he's lost popularity in Missouri.
State Sec.
CARNAHAN: Sure.
And so I don't think this election in the end is going to be about President Obama.
I think it's going to be a choice between two candidates with records in public service and I think that's what Missourians will look to.
Secretary of State Robin Carnahan, thank you very much for talking with us.
State Sec.
CARNAHAN: Thank you.
The polls say this race is close, but the political consultants I spoke with pointed to a number that will be a better indicator come November, the unemployment rate.
If that rate is down, Robin Carnahan can win, they say.
But, Michele, if it stays where it is, they say that's very hard to see.
Now, Robert, after spending time in Missouri, I'm curious about what you find most striking about this race.
Well, I was struck by both candidates speaking of ending uncertainties.
The uncertainty of the inheritance tax, it goes away and then comes back higher, or the uncertainty of the health care mandate.
Ray Blunt talked about that.
He'd like to see that reduced for small businesses.
It's a measure of how uncertain things are for small business nowadays.
So, a lot of uncertainty in the state.
If you happen to live in Missouri, are you seeing and hearing this nonstop on the airwaves?
No.
No. This race has not gone on television, as they say, in advertising.
I heard a couple of reasons for that.
One explanation was with the candidates not knowing how much national money there's going to be, how many races will be in play, theyre husbanding their resources and not spending a lot of money now.

I also heard an interesting observation that with cuts in the news business, especially in the newspapers, there just may be less newspaper coverage, driving less media coverage of this race and so it's hard to get voters' attention.
Missouri was a state that was very important to the Obama campaign, in part because of Claire McCaskill's early support.
How does President Obama figure into this race?
He has lost a great deal of popularity there.
His favorability ratings are down in Missouri.
On the other hand, President George W.
Bush and the Republican congress aren't that fondly remembered either.
So this is a race between two candidates, neither of whom has a big national party to align with.
But both of whom come from very famous Missouri families and that's what they're counting on.
It's MORNING EDITION from NPR News.
Good morning.
I'm Steve Inskeep.
Oh, of course, why not?
I would love to actually have a party where you put Jell-O in Jell-O, where you would suspend in Jell-O actual boxes of Jell-O or even little plastic cups that you can buy nowadays.
That would be the (unintelligible) of the Jell-O in Jell-O suspended routine.
Yeah.
And again, these things required molds, molds the size of a bathtub.
So my concern is that by construing cyberspace as a place of conflict, we will effectively see a trend developing amongst Western governments that questions how the Internet is currently managed.
Now, governments don't have that much to say in cyberspace currently.
It's run by the private sector, and it's built by civil society, right?
So that dialogue is changing.
And it seems to be implying that we're shifting into a direction where government would take over much more responsibility than it's previously had.
Now, this is exactly what countries like Russia and China would like.
So it's really a case of trying to make sure that we, in the Western governments, don't allow our governments to be distracted.
It's important to understand that cyberspace is an information domain.
So all our political opinions, all our purchasing decisions, the way we educate our children, everything is in cyberspace.
And we have to take extraordinary care that authoritarian interests don't gain more than a toehold in this domain.
Alex Klimburg, thanks very much.
Thank you very much for your time.
Alex Klimburg of Harvard and The Hague Center for Strategic Studies.
His new book is ""The Darkening Web: The War For Cyberspace.
(SOUNDBITE OF GOLD PANDA'S ""SONG FOR A DEAD FRIEND (DAISUKE TANABE REMIX)"")
Author James Lileks calls the 1930s, '40s and '50s the golden age of American cookery.
His new book ""Gastroanomalies"" looks back on dishes like the Burning Bush, Dried Beef, Philadelphia Cream Cheese and Grapefruit, the Corned Beef Salad Loaf and the Meat Upside Down Cake.
Lileks' book is filled with ads and old photographs and recipes for dishes he describes as monuments to an era.
Did anybody actually make this stuff and did anybody actually eat it?
Call us with your culinary regrets and confessions from the '50s.
Our number is 800-989-8255.
E-mail is talk@npr.org.
And comment on our blog at npr.org/blogofthenation, where there's an excerpt from James Lileks' books and a few photographs, too.
And James Lileks joins us now from Minnesota Public Radio in St. Paul.
Nice to have you on the program today.
And welcome from preposterously cold Minnesota…
Preposterously cold.
It's getting colder here in Washington, D.C.
I am looking at a picture on page 12 of your book.
These…
Oh, you poor man.
These eggs, you write, resemble creamed bile with mustard sauce, and the ubiquitous white fluid makes it impossible to eat this with your hands.
The meat's nice and clammy, but really: Is there enough fat in this dish?
If your corpuscles don't have to go single-file through your major arteries, you can still indulge in a little more.
Have two.
These are grotesque-looking pieces of food.
That - they are, and that's the pleasure.
You know, for all I know, nobody made any of these stuff.

For all I know, the housewives of the '30s, '40s and '50s put these things down and steadied themselves with a little Bromo-Seltzer, put their hand over their stomach and hope that it would pass and just moved on to cooking the things that they knew the family would like.

But for some reason, the manufacturers of food, the recipe companies, the magazines, all put out these pictures of - if ghastly is the word - of these strange, oleaginous, glistening dishes that they thought people would like.
Once you start looking for them, you can't - you can't be - you're stunned by the quantity of inedible food that they seemed to think people should make in those days.
And many…
Again…
…of the worst - I'm sorry, I didn't mean to cut you off.
